normalised: **Quora Post: Rental Yields - What's up, bro?**

unnormalised: Hey guys, so I've been dabbling in real estate in Mumbai, and everyone keeps throwing around the term "rental yield." It sounds complicated, but it's actually pretty straightforward.
normalised: Hey guys, so I've been dabbling in real estate in Mumbai, and everyone keeps throwing around the term "rental yield." It sounds complicated, but it's actually pretty straightforward.

unnormalised: Basically, it's the annual rental income you get from a property, expressed as a percentage of its purchase price (or current market value). Think of it as the return you're getting on your investment.
normalised: Basically, it's the annual rental income you get from a property, expressed as a percentage of its purchase price (or current market value). Think of it as the return you're getting on your investment.

unnormalised: For example, if you bought a flat in Powai for Rs. 1 Crore (Rs. 1,00,00,000) and rent it out for Rs. 30,000 per month, your annual rental income is Rs. 3,60,000 (30,000 x 12). Your rental yield is then (3,60,000/1,00,00,000) x 100 = 3.6%.
normalised: For example, if you bought a flat in Powai for rupee one crore (rupee one, zero zero, zero zero, zero zero zero) and rent it out for rupee thirty thousand per month, your annual rental income is rupee three lakh sixty thousand (thirty thousand multiplied by twelve). Your rental yield is then (three lakh sixty thousand divided by one crore) multiplied by one hundred equals three point six percent.

unnormalised: Now, a "good" rental yield depends on a lot of things - location, type of property (flat, independent house, etc.), and even the time of year. You might get better deals around Diwali because people are festive, but they might not be actively looking for rentals.
normalised: Now, a "good" rental yield depends on a lot of things - location, type of property (flat, independent house, etcetera), and even the time of year. You might get better deals around Diwali because people are festive, but they might not be actively looking for rentals.

unnormalised: Don't forget to factor in property taxes, maintenance costs, and even things like broker commissions. These all eat into your yield. Think of it like that amazing biryani your mom makes – all the ingredients contribute to the final flavour, right? Same with rental yield calculations.

unnormalised: Places like Bangalore, Chennai, and Pune often have relatively good rental yields compared to Mumbai, especially with the IT sector booming there. IIT graduates are always looking for rentals near their workplaces, driving up demand.
